courseDescription: This course focuses on the concept of leisure and its impact on health and wellness for individuals and groups. Fundamental principles, philosophies, and theories of leisure, health, and wellness are emphasized. Leisure’s relationships with physical, cognitive, social, emotional, and spiritual growth, human satisfaction, and quality of life are explored. Leisure’s influence on challenges to wellness experienced by diverse populations (e.g., individuals with disabilities, older adults, racial and ethnic groups, individuals identifying as LGBTQIA+) is examined. Strategies for protecting and promoting health through leisure are integrated throughout the course.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Understanding and addressing the needs of diverse populations
Effective communication with individuals identifying as LGBTQIA+
Cultural sensitivity and awareness in communication
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of the impact of leisure on health and wellness
Identification and implementation of strategies for promoting health through leisure
Understanding and addressing challenges to wellness in diverse populations
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning and implementation of health-promoting leisure activities
Leadership in promoting physical, cognitive, social, emotional, and spiritual growth through leisure

courseDescription: This course is designed to be an introduction to the historical and conceptual roots of recreational therapy. Content includes recreational therapy service delivery models, legislation, professional organizations, places of practice, ethical conduct, and credentialing procedures.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of recreational therapy service delivery models
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ethical conduct in recreational therapy practice
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of historical and conceptual roots of recreational therapy
Understanding legislation related to recreational therapy
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Navigating places of practice in recreational therapy

courseDescription: This course is designed to facilitate personal exploration and professional preparation for careers in recreational therapy. Topics include professional ethics, professional involvement, professional behaviors & responsibilities, and career preparation. On-site observation of recreational therapists in practice settings is required.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Understanding and adhering to professional behaviors & responsibilities
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Career planning
Problem-solving in professional settings

courseDescription: This course is designed to provide students with the skills and knowledge required to successfully acquire an internship placement in recreational therapy.  Emphasis will be placed on resume and cover letters, internship search strategies, interviewing skills, and internship documentation requirements.  Students are required to become familiar with all documentation requirements in the Recreational Therapy Internship Manual, and successfully secure an internship for the following semester.
Technical and Digital Skills: Familiarity with Recreational Therapy Internship Manual
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identification and securing of appropriate internship placements

courseDescription: This course requires a 200-hour junior internship experience at an approved health and human service agency in which students are involved with ongoing recreational therapy programs. Students are expected to observe and assist recreational therapy staff during this field experience. Students must be supervised by a Certified Therapeutic Recreation Specialist (CTRS) working for the agency.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of health and human service agency operations
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Interacting with health and human service agency staff
Cooperation with Certified Therapeutic Recreation Specialist (CTRS)
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adaptation to the work environment of a health and human service agency
Understanding and assisting in the implementation of recreational therapy programs
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Observing and following leadership of CTRS

courseDescription: This course is designed to introduce students to a wide variety of Recreational Therapy interventions. Students will explore physical, cognitive, and psychosocial interventions. Facilitation techniques, activity modification, and group facilitation will be explored. Students will connect diagnostic groups to specific Recreational Therapy interventions. Students will facilitate group recreational therapy interventions during lab.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of physical, cognitive, and psychosocial interventions in Recreational Therapy
Ability to connect diagnostic groups to specific Recreational Therapy interventions
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to communicate therapeutic techniques effectively
Experience in facilitating group recreational therapy interventions
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Ability to analyze different Recreational Therapy interventions
Problem-solving skills in modifying activities for varied needs
Analytical skills in connecting diagnostic groups to specific interventions
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leadership skills in facilitating group interventions
Organizational skills in planning and implementing therapeutic interventions

courseTitle: Assessment, Documentation, and Evaluation in Recreational Therapy
courseDescription: This course will provide students with a detailed examination of assessment, documentation, and evaluation procedures used in the recreation therapy treatment process. Course focus includes the assessment and documentation process, including instrument design, selection, and implementation, and the reporting and use of data for treatment planning and program evaluation.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Data-driven treatment planning
Evaluating program effectiveness
Selective use of assessment instruments

courseDescription: This course is designed to introduce students to a variety of disabilities, illnesses, and health conditions recreational therapists may encounter in practice. The prevalence, etiology, diagnostic criteria, pathology, symptomatology, and prognosis of various conditions is presented, and the bio-psycho-social impact of the illness/disability on the individual and family is discussed. Emphasis is placed on the delivery of recreational therapy services for individuals with illnesses/disabilities and related populations.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of various disabilities, illnesses, and health conditions
Knowledge of diagnostic criteria and pathology
Familiarity with recreational therapy services and their application
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Empathy and understanding for individuals with illnesses/disabilities
Ability to communicate effectively with patients and their families
Coordination with medical professionals and other stakeholders
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing the bio-psycho-social impact of illnesses/disabilities
Identifying suitable recreational therapy services for specific conditions
Evaluating the effectiveness of recreational therapy interventions
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning and delivering recreational therapy services
Leading a team of recreational therapists
Coordinating patient care in a complex medical environment

courseDescription: This course explores the basic principles of organizing and managing quality recreational therapy services. Content includes supervisory and administrative responsibilities, budgeting, managing personnel including student interns and volunteers, developing a clinical supervision program, marketing recreational therapy services, and developing a recreational therapy department based on professional standards of practice and recreational therapy models of service delivery.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Organizing quality recreational therapy services
Managing student interns and volunteers
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Developing a recreational therapy department based on professional standards of practice and recreational therapy models of service delivery

courseDescription: This capstone course requires a 560-hour and 14-week senior internship experience at an approved health and human service agency practicing recreational therapy. Students will apply academic learning and will demonstrate competencies associated with entry-level practice in recreational therapy. The student’s academic and agency direct supervisors must be Certified Therapeutic Recreation Specialists.
Technical and Digital Skills: Application of academic learning in recreational therapy
Adherence to health and human service agency protocols
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Professional communication with agency staff and clients
Collaboration with certified therapeutic recreation specialists
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adaptation to real-world therapeutic scenarios
Demonstration of competencies associated with entry-level practice in recreational therapy
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Management of a 560-hour and 14-week internship experience
Maintaining professional relationships with academic and agency direct supervisors

courseTitle: Recreational Therapy Program Design and Implementation
courseDescription: This skill-based course is designed to further students’ practical understanding of client-centered recreational therapy program design and implementation using evidence-based strategies, techniques, and interventions. Emphasis is placed on the purpose, roles, and outcomes of recreational therapy service delivery in healthcare and community settings. Topics include assessment, recreational therapy practice models, specific program planning, task analysis, facilitation techniques, implementation of evidence-based interventions, documentation, and evaluation of services as well as interprofessional practice. Field-based application of course concepts is required.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Service delivery in healthcare and community settings
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Use of evidence-based strategies, techniques, and interventions
Evaluation of services
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding roles and outcomes of recreational therapy service delivery

courseTitle: Evidence-Based Practice and Trends in Recreational Therapy
courseDescription: This course provides an overview of evidence-based practice and related disciplinary writing in recreational therapy contexts. Through exploration of current trends and issues in the field of therapeutic recreation and a writing intensive approach, students develop skills in evaluating and interpreting research and applying applicable findings through evidence-based practice, service to the field, and professional advocacy. This is a writing intensive course.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of Current Trends and Issues in Therapeutic Recreation

courseDescription: Individualized instruction to include research, specialized studies, or other scholarly writing.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Research problem identification
Analysis of research data
Critical thinking

courseDescription: Supervised research on a specific problem in recreational therapy. Regular meetings with faculty and a written/oral report are required.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem identification
Analyzing research data
Developing solutions
